column1: Promises tax break for school uniforms
column3: JULIA Gillard has unveiled her first election promise, offering parents a tax break of up to almost $800 to cover the cost of school uniforms. The pledge - to cost about $220 million over four years. The refund - worth up to $390 for a primary school child and $779 for a secondary student - will not become available until families lodge their tax returns in 2012-13.

Promise to spend is equivalent to save
column3: By making sure that any promise we make to spend money is offset by a promise to save money.
By making sure that the budget bottom line doesn't change by one cent during the election campaign.

column1: To build a $2.6 billion rail link between Parramatta and Epping.
column3: Preliminary work on the 14-kilometre heavy rail link, which will shave 25 minutes off the trip from Chatswood to Parramatta, will begin next year [2010] and construction is due to be completed in 2017. To ensure the state government delivers on its end of the deal, the project will be overseen by the federal government's infrastructure body, Infrastructure Australia.
Labor has provided more help for pensioners through increases of more than $100 a fortnight in the age pension for singles and $76 for couples.

column1: Julia Gillard and Labor have a plan to get the budget back in the black with a surplus in 3 years.
Establishing a single national school curriculum
column3: The new English, maths, science and history curriculum was the subject of extensive consultation this year and is currently being road tested in schools around Australia. The next phase of work has commenced to develop the National Curriculum for languages, geography and the arts.

column1: From July 1 this year, the Gillard Labor Government began delivering $7.3 billion in health investments over the next five years.

column1: Medicare rebates for consultations by internet
column3: those in rural, remote and outer metropolitan areas would receive Medicare rebates for consultations by internet with far-away specialists, and GPs and specialists would get financial incentives to take part. And by July 1, 2012, patients would be able to consult after hours via video-conferencing doctors and specialists.

column3:
The Princes Highway East - Traralgon to Sale duplication involves widening the Princes Highway between Traralgon and Sale to provide two lanes in each direction. This will ultimately result in a four lane, two carriageway freeway which will cover road works over approximately 44 kilometres in total. 

Construction will be undertaken in several sections, commencing with the Traralgon East Section between Traralgon-Maffra Road and Stammers Road.
column12: Funding for this commitment will be fully offset over the forward estimates
